claim: Paul Dirac, a Jewish physicist born in Britain, won the Nobel Prize for Physics.

supporting.text: Paul Dirac was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933, jointly with Erwin Schrödinger, for their contributions to the discovery of new productive forms of atomic theory.

attacks.text: Paul Dirac was awarded the Nobel Prize in Physics in 1933, jointly with Erwin Schrödinger, for their contributions to the discovery of new productive forms of atomic theory.

attacks.text: Dirac's formulation of the Dirac equation, which describes the behavior of fermions and predicted the existence of antimatter, was a groundbreaking contribution to quantum mechanics and a key reason for his Nobel Prize.

While the Dirac equation was groundbreaking, the Nobel Prize was awarded jointly to Dirac and Schrödinger in 1933, and Schrödinger's wave mechanics was equally recognized as foundational to quantum mechanics.

Schrödinger's wave mechanics was indeed foundational, but Dirac's equation uniquely unified quantum mechanics with special relativity and predicted antimatter, which was experimentally verified later, making his contribution distinctively Nobel-worthy.
